p: Since the yeast-to-hypha transition is an important virulence factor associated with the pathogenesis of C. albicans infections, the effect of the oils on the germ tube formation in C. albicans ATCC 10231 was assessed. As shown in Table 3, both essential oils inhibited the germ tube formation at concentrations well below their respective MIC, with T. camphoratus being more effective and attaining ca. 40% inhibition at 0.07 mg/mL (MIC/16). Fluconazole (MIC = 0.001 mg/mL), the antifungal drug of choice in the clinic for the management of candidiasis, failed to inhibit this feature even at concentrations much higher than its MIC. Indeed, even at 0.2 mg/mL, that corresponds to fluconazole’s MIC×200 ( Table 4), the antifungal drug was completely ineffective.
